awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE:Biology Teaching Assistant Project (BioTAP 2.0): Advancing Research, Synthesizing Evidence
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI team from the University of Tennessee Knoxville, the University of Maryland College Park, Middle Tennessee State University, University of Georgia, and Ohio State University has received a Research Coordination Network - Undergraduate Biology Education (RCN-UBE) award for their project entitled Biology Teaching Assistant Project (BioTAP 2.0): Advancing Research, Synthesizing Evidence.   The project is building a sustainable collaborative network to support, synthesize, and disseminate biology Graduate Teaching Assistant (GTA) Teaching Professional Development (TPD) research results and to advocate for community TPD standards with the potential to increase the effectiveness of GTA TPD nationwide.   BioTAP 2.0 is improving undergraduate biology education by expanding the network of 80 institutions developed during their RCN-UBE Incubator project.  In that way the project is increasing the number and diversity of institutions involved in GTA TPD, both practice and research. 

BioTAP 2.0 also is creating and implementing Research Development Sessions and Virtual Learning Communities to foster collaborative research on biology GTA TPD. These are inter- and intra-institutional collaborative teams to develop TPD research projects using common research tools and methods.  BioTAP 2.0 is also synthesizing, disseminating, and advocating for research to identify empirically-based best practices in GTA TPD. By developing standardized TPD research practices and innovative face-to-face and virtual sessions to guide research practitioners, the project is fulfilling the potential to synthesize research results that will improve undergraduate biology education across the nation.  This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/.

por.por_cntn:
Public Outcomes Summary, November 2021

The goal of BioTAP was to form a network of Biology Graduate Teaching Assistant (GTA) Teaching Professional Development (TPD) providers, and advance the capacity of those individuals to generate empirical data to inform the enhancement of GTA TPD practices. In addition to providing resources and virtual conference opportunities for the 250 network members interested in improving Biology GTA TPD, project leaders also implemented the BioTAP Scholars Program which guided 66 participants through the development and implementation of a GTA TPD research project. The Scholars program fostered research collaborations across institutions, increased the visibility of GTA TPD as a lever for improving undergraduate education at institutions, and advanced the professional careers of the participants. Over the six years of the project, we established BioTAP as the premier network for professional development and advocacy for TPD providers and improvement of GTA TPD practices. Our project objectives with relevant outcomes are below.

Objective 1: Expand and support collaborations with all biology GTA TPD stakeholders including researchers, educators, administrators, and graduate students. The BioTAP network grew from 81 to over 250 diverse participants over the 6 years of the project. Of this group, 66 network members were admitted to the BioTAP Scholars program. In 2017 we created further opportunities for collaboration when we organized and hosted a virtual conference on GTA TPD that has occurred annually since that time. Pre-post assessments show significant increases in collaborative discussion among BioTAP members about research and practice related to GTA TPD.

Objective 2: Create and Implement Research Development Sessions and Virtual Learning Communities to foster collaborative research on biology GTA TPD. We successfully ran four cohorts of the BioTAP Scholars Program and mentored 66 individuals through year-long research projects on GTA TPD. The Scholars program materials were iteratively refined each year and are provided on the BioTAP website (www.biotap.org) for others to use as a template for training programs and will be published in an upcoming volume of CourseSource.

Objective 3: Synthesize, disseminate, and advocate for research to identify empirically based best practices in biology GTA TPD. The project team compiled the literature on Biology GTA TPD and creating an annotated, sortable database of this research. The BioTAP Scholars generated 2 articles and 14 conference presentations related to their GTA TPD research, and 78% surveyed said they would continue GTA TPD research at their institution, showing the potential to increase new research through this program. In terms of advocacy, we generated administrator letters and position statements that were sent to administrators of BioTAP Scholars and these were anecdotally effective in raising awareness of GTA TPD and Scholars at their institution.

Future of BioTAP: One of the final tasks of the network was to consider the sustainability of BioTAP. An independent Sustainability Task Force worked in spring 2021 to make suggestions to the PI team about how to continue the work of the network. In late 2021, this resulted in the formation of a Governance Task Force and three BioTAP committees comprised of 40 individuals who will guide the network into the future.


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Elisabeth E Schussler
